text: A piercing high note is sustained on the soundtrack as th main title, "CRYSTAL JAPAN" speeds straight at the audien in 3-D and seems to jump right out at them.
The opening credits follow.  Ominous theme music fills th soundtrack, growing darker and more dissonant.
The theme music slowly dissolves into the sound of a radi news broadcast, as the credits continue to unfold.
...and I'm Ed Harris with the KLTZ Early Morning Report.
Theme music out.

(continuing) Crystal Lake in Pinehurst County, the scene of several unsolved deaths years ago, is tragically back in the top of the news this morning.  Police have uncovered the remains of eight, as yet, unidentified persons in a gruesome and baffling story of mass murder...
End credits.

Shooting over a line of ruffled bushes with leaves just turning towards a rural, time-worn country market.  A wid gravel parking area makes it accessible to the highway running past it, otherwise, this Mom & Pop store seems al like a vision of times gone by.
The bushes and overgrown grass, unrestrained by any human care, strengthen the sense of isolation.  The dying sun shoots its last rays through the trees behind the market.
The market has a battered second-story: the living quarte of the people running it.  A truck roars by.  Then silenc and then again the sound of the radio news report:
...Judging from the sheer brutality of the murders, police theorize that they must have been committed by at least four persons...

Sagging clotheslines cluttered with drying laundry run ac a narrow backyard, all the way to a rickety old shed.  Th clotheslines are supported by one solitary pole.  Linen a garments billow in the rising evening breeze.
Cold, foreboding music accompanies the camera as it moves toward a pair of flapping khaki pants and an olive green workshirt hanging side by side on the line.
The radio news report grows louder as the clothing snaps directly into the lens.

...The sole survivor of the massacre has been taken under heavy sedation to County Hospital in Linfield for observation. She's been unable to provide police with any clues and is being kept under round the clock guard...

And then a man parts two shrouds of wet laundry, making h way back towards the house.  This is HAROLD: 40ish, paunc unshaven and so clumsy that he hits the clothesline pole knocks it down, burying himself under a heap of linen.  A transistor radio pops out of the pocket of his threadbare shirt, still broadcasting the news.  One of the upstairs windows opens with a creak, and
Harold's wife, sticks her head out and looks into the backyard:
(loud, harsh) Goddamnit Harold!  I spent all day yesterday washing your clothes and look what you're doing to 'em. Shows how much you care about me.
Harold watches her from under the pile of laundry.  Then grabs the radio, staggers up, increasing the radio's volu as he does so, to drown out the voice of his wife.
Above him, Edna raves on for a moment (we can't make out she is saying), then furiously slams the window shut.

The room is musty and cluttered like an old attic.  Edna stomps away from the window and turns her attention to th partially functional, old clunker of a black and white TV She plops herself down onto the lumpy couch and picks up knitting needles and returns to work on a sweater.  A new report about the mass murders is being broadcast.

...A police spokesman tells Eyewitness News that authorities have been combing the area since just before dawn.  Reports of cannibalism and sexual mutilation are still unconfirmed... Nevertheless, these murders are already being called the most brutal in local history.
Leans in to adjust the long rabbit-ear antenna, spreading ears apart for a better picture.  She listens intently.
The motive behind the grisly murders remains a mystery at this hour as does the identity of the killer or killers.  The search continues for more bodies.
(to herself) My God, My God, My God.

...Residents of the Lake region are being urged to take extra precaution when approaching strangers and to report anything unusual to police, immediately. We'll be back with the weather forecast after this important message.
Visibly upset, Edna rises to her feet.  She goes over to door leading downstairs to the market, opens it and call
Harold, what're you doing down there?
No response.  She rushes to the window, jerks it open and sticks her head out.
(continuing) Harold... I want to talk to you.
No answer.
of the backyard.  The laundry quietly swells in the wind. For an instant, a human form is visible between layers of drying clothes.  From this distance, Edna can't make out it is.
Harold?
Unnerved by the continuing noise of the TV, Edna goes bac shut it off.  She quickly returns to the window and looks again.
No sign of anyone, but there is an empty span of clothesl where several articles of clothes were hung, only a secon before.
Edna runs for the apartment door.
Edna flies down the stairs and enters the store from the back.  The market is dark, save does shafts of dying sunl through the grimy front windows. She scans the few aisles back and forth.
Harold?

A big rabbit appears from behind an arrangement of Campbe soup cans, and stands on its hind legs on the aisle, tryi to guess Edna's next move.  Still calling Harold, she tur starts at the sight of the rabbit; she grabs a tomato fro the produce display, throw it at the animal.
(continuing) God Damn pest, what are you staring at?
She misses, grabs more vegetables and hurls them at the rabbit.  The rabbit dodges them, and scurries away.
The sunlight is almost gone, stretching the shadows even more.  In her nightgown, Edna pushed open the creaky scre door and steps out into the backyard.
Shooting towards her through the laundry flapping on the clothesline.  As she touches a set of pajamas and finds o that they are still wet.

A shoulder suddenly enters the flame, and someone's silhouette blocks the screen just for a couple of seconds before the intruder slips behind another curtain of dryin clothes, revealing Edna again:  she's still checking the clothes and hasn't noticed anything.

She comes to where the trousers and workshirt were, and n longer.  That's a shock, but she's not quite sure that th were here in the first place, so she goes on, and starts talking to herself to fortify her ailing courage.

Christ All Mighty, Harold, you just take what's yours and leave the rest for me to do.  Very considerate! (collecting the dry laundry and putting it in a basket) You could at least finished the job.  Do I have to do everything around here?
Edna hears a noise and whips around.  Her imagination is working overtime. A bedsheet is swelling slowly in the breeze, taking the s of a human body.  Is anyone behind it?  Ominous music...
(swallowing hard) Harold... I swear, sometimes you're such a child...
She charges forward.  She rips the sheet off the line and falls in a heap with it.  There is no one behind it.
She turns over and lays on her back.  Above her, there's the dark evening sky and the branches of a tree, rustling back and forth.
Edna gets up and quickly pulls the remaining laundry off lines, tossing it into the basket.  As she does, she pass near the wooden shed at the back of the store.
The shed door creak open.  Edna turns around.  Suddenly, there's a crashing noise from inside.  That's enough for Edna... she hauls up the basket and rushes back inside th store.
The white rabbit that gave Edna such a scare is now hoppi across a row of canned goods.  A man's hand enters frame grabs the rabbit by the nape of its neck and lifts it off shelf, into his arms.

It's Harold.  He places the rabbit on his shoulder and gr a jar of peanuts from the shelf.  He twists open the vacu sealed jar and wolfs down a handful of its contents.  Wit another handful, he feeds the rabbit, who sniffs and part
Harold rescrews the lid and places it back on the shelf. turns on the radio in his breast pocket.  Music blares.
He grabs his broom and starts sweeping down the aisle, th rabbit remaining contentedly on his shoulder.
Harold stops at the dairy case and grabs a half-gallon ju milk.  He breaks the seal and pulls off the cap.  He firs offers the rabbit a taste, then gulps down a swig himself
An unidentified face, in soft focus, peers in through the storefront window then disappears almost as quickly.  Har is unaware.
screws the cap back on and replaces the jug in the case.
The sound of crunching and munching.
Harold turns around.  The the produce section, the cellop packages of carrots on display are moving slightly.
He reaches in and pushes off the top few packages to reve underneath, another rabbit, a grey one this time, nibblin a carrot.
He lifts the rabbit out of the case and places it on his opposite shoulder.
(looking from one rabbit to the other) Sorry guys, it's back to the slammer before Edna make a fur coat out of ya.
On his way to the back door, Harold passes a rack of cake and pies.  He stops long enough to open a box of six chocolate-covered donuts.  He takes one out and shoves it into his mouth.
Unbeknownst to Harold, a human form in shadow appears at back door.  The door is quietly pushed open.  Someone is watching him.
The camera as stalker enters the store and moves slowly towards Harold, his back to us.  Ominous music accompanie the approach.
Checks filled to capacity.  Harold closes the package and puts it back in place on the rack, hiding it under severa unopened packages.
Harold turns.  The stalker is right behind him, completel startled, he jumps back and chokes on the doughnuts.  The rabbits hop off his shoulders.
Unexpectedly, Harold find himself face to face... with hi wife, Edna.
Didn't I feed you enough for breakfast?
Harold doesn't answer.
(continuing) The doctor said you had to lose weight, didn't he?  I try to help you but you sneak food behind my back.  What am I gonna do with you?
Without a word, Harold bends down to retrieve the rabbits He scoops them up in his arms.
(continuing) And put those filthy animals back where they belong, please!
Harold exits by way of the back door.

Harold puts the grey rabbit on his shoulder, the white ra remains wrapped in his arms.  He swallows the rest of the doughnut in his mouth as he flips a flashlight out of his back pocket and ambles across the yard.
Light filters through the cracked walls partially illuminating a variety of tools, old barrels, various odd ends - and a rabbit hutch.
Harold flicks on the flashlight as he enters.  The rabbit atop his shoulder jumps off and scurries away.  The rabbi his arms squirms and squeals.  The animals sense that something is wrong.
(stroking the white rabbit) What're you little guys so nervous about?
He scans the shed with the flashlight to locate the runaw as he tries to contain the jittery ball of fur in his arm The flashlight searches each corner, until the beam final stops on:
Music pounds hard on the soundtrack, as through the hutch grillwork we can see a mass of dead rabbits, lying one ne to the other, staring up with glinting, glass eyes.
Harold stands immobilized, in a state of shock.  He looks down upon the limp bodies of his beloved pets, his face turned into a sad mask of outrage.  He holds onto the whi rabbit even tighter.
Who would do this...?
Trembling, Harold reaches to lift the lid of the hutch. music throbs...
A big timber rattlesnake springs out of the hutch, mouth and open, twin poisonous fangs shining in the beam of the flashlight.
The music drops out as the snake's loud kiss dominates. muscles of its dark, lean body push the deadly mouth ahea into the lens of the camera.
Instinctively, Harold slams the hutch down, dropping his flashlight and the white rabbit.  The snake hisses and sp at the camera through the wife mesh.
Literally scared shitless, Harold races out of the shed, holding his stomach with both hands.
Harold dashes through the back door, and up the stairs li a charging bull.
Harold bursts through the door, crashing into his unsuspecting wife.  Edna is knocked off balance and tries hold onto him.
What happened?  What's the matter?
Harold can't talk.  He rubs his stomach and heads straigh for the bathroom, vanishing inside.
(continuing) It's all the crap you've been stuffing yourself with.
Edna turns up the volume on the TV and plunks herself dow the couch.
She reaches for her knitting bag and empties its contents One of her two, long, thin knitting needles is missing.
(rummaging all around her) Now where could that other needle have gone?

The room is a combination:  storing place mostly, there a two ample cupboards facing each other, each leaning again a wall, a mess of crates and boxes lying on top of each o behind a dusty curtain... and a toilet bowl, left from th days when this was just an oversized bathroom.  The toile bowl is against the fourth wall, at an angle behind the d
The sound of the TV filters through the door as Harold, trousers down to his knees, sits on the toilet, sighing w relief as the first bout of diarrhea is over.
He loosens his collar, wipes some sweat from his brow, reaches behind the toilet tank, and produces a hidden bot of Whiskey.
He unscrews the cap and takes a hardy swig.  He leans bac and shut his eyes.
(to himself) Those poor little creatures...
Another swig.  Some of the liquor spills over his chin an wipes it with his sleeve.  His eyes wander around aimless then focus on...
partially masking the mess of boxes and crates.  It seems ripple subtly, moved by an ever so slight movement of air perhaps someone's breath?
Harold waits.  The curtains seem still.  Harold is about relax when a brief, hollow noise is heard.

Harold tries to locate the noise, but it's over before he tell its source.  Pants around his ankles, he rises, shuf to one of the closets.  It takes some courage to yank the door open, and the camera moves fast into a...
FLAT CLOSEUP of empty shelves - nothing has touched them a long time, except dust.

Breathing relief, Harold pulls up his pants again, just enough to be able to hobble grotesquely to the dusty curt He rips it apart, stares at the odd assortment of boxes a crates - empty, lifeless, and uncannily menacing because their lifelessness.
Reassured, Harold gives the other closet a glance, almost decides against checking it - and then changes his mind, stumbles, pants still around his ankles, towards it.

Looks like this one hasn't been opened at all for a long time.  Harold tugs at the door - a creak, followed instan by a musical stinger as a huge hand holding a meat cleave rips into the shot, strikes Harold, imbedding the cleaver his chest.
Harold manages a half-scream that mixes incongruously wit the laughter from the TV in the living room.  As the hand twists the cleaver, the scream becomes a raspy cough.
Harold stumbles backwards and crashes to the floor.
Edna hears the crash.  She turns off the television.
Harold?
No answer.  She gets up from the couch and goes to the bathroom door.  She listens and hears the noise of the to flushing and flushing, as if someone's hand never release the lever.
(rattling the door knob) Harold... what's taking you so long in there?  You all right?
She pushes against the door.  It doesn't budge.  She look down and notices some kind of liquid seeping out from underneath the bathroom door.  She dips her fingers in it sniffs.
(continuing) Whiskey, I thought so.
She goes over to a desk, opens a small drawer and finds a skeleton key.
She hurries back to the bathroom/storeroom door, ready to insert the key.  To her shock, the door is now open a cra
For a moment, Edna is nonplussed.
(continuing) Harold!
She pushes the door - it swings open, revealing the open closets, the boxes and crates...
Edna steps inside and inadvertently kicks the half-empty bottle of Whiskey.  She picks up the bottle while the flushing noise persists maddeningly.
She turns toward the toilet, which is behind the door and screams at the sight of Harold sitting there.
pants down, like a grotesque dummy, blood drooling out of corners of his mouth, the meat cleaver sticking out of hi chest and one elbow stuck against the flushing handle.
The Whiskey bottle falls from Edna's hand, hits the floor shatters.
Edna screams uncontrollably.

From behind her a huge hand enters the flame and pierces back of her head with the previously missing knitting nee The needle is pushed out through her mouth, right at the camera. she gags on her own blood and slums out of frame.
A group ethnic children are playing stickball in the stre weatherworn two and three-family houses on either side of them.

A red passenger van screeches around the corner and heads down the block, slowing down as it advances on the oblivi children.  The driver sounds the horn, warning of the van approach.  Most of the children scatter, but a few don't, yelling and banging on the sides of the van as it passes.
The van continues for a few yards then parallel parks in first available space.

The driver Chris...19, blond, attractive but intense...st down and circles around to the passenger side where two others jump out.  They are Debbie...19, brown-haired, vivacious and healthy, the all-american cheerleader type...and Andy...slims, athletic and ruggedly handsome.
Which one is it?
(pointing) It's the last house on the left. She lives downstairs.
Chris turns back to the van.
(calling through window) Hey Shelly!  Come on out and meet your date.
(from inside van) Bring her to me!
Chris looks back at Andy and Debbie for advice.
(shrugging his shoulder) What're you gonna do?
Maybe this wasn't such a good idea.
Chris calls into the van once again.
How about you two?  You coming?
Two other voices shout back:
(in unison) No!
Chris throws up her hands in frustration, joining Andy an Debbie.  They cross the street abreast.

CAMERA TRACKS in front of the three friends.  A rotund, ominous-looking figure in a hideous, ghostly white mask springs out from around the hidden side of the van.  The figure follows a safe distance behind the unsuspecting threesome, brandishing a knife.
As they walk, Andy and Debbie are locked in each other's and they begin to kiss.  Chris looks at them and shakes h head.
Sex, sex, sex.  You guys are getting boring, you know that?
Debbie breaks the kiss, feeling a little embarrassed.
So what would a weekend in the country be without sex?
(stern) Cool it, Andy.
(apologetic) I didn't mean it the way it sounded...
I know you didn't...
Little by little, the masked figure advances from behind.
(to Andy and Debbie) Look guys, I don't want to ruin your weekend.  What happened to me at the cottage happened a long time ago and I think I've worked that out. I'm all right now.
The figure draws even closer raising the knife above his
(continuing) I appreciate the fact that you worry about me, but don't.
Okay, we won't.  We'll just have fun, all agreed?
The masked figure rears back and plunges the knife into Andy's back.
Aaahhh!
The rubber knife bends in half.  Andy, Debbie and Chris w around to face the assailant.
(continuing) Dammit Shelly!  Why do you always have to be such an asshole!
(still wearing the mask) I beg your pardon, I'm not an asshole.  I'm an actor.
Same thing.
Chris and Debbie, in disgust, turn away and walk off.  An drops back to walk with Shelly.

(paternal) Look Shelly, you're my roommate and I like you... most of the time.  But you gotta stop doing these things.  Now, I set this date up for you, didn't I?  So don't embarrass me.  When you meet this woman, just relax and be yourself.
Would you be yourself... (ripping off mask) ...if you looked this this?
Shelly puts on a pair of unflattering prescription glasse Although he has a pleasant face, Shelly is overweight, gr haired and unkempt.
Chris and Debbie lead the way for Andy and Shelly up the porch steps, to the front door of a shabby, two-family ho
Chris rings the bell.  Shelly takes a few steps back.  He mats down his unruly hair, tucks in his shirt and takes o his glasses.  He's ready.
The door opens and a middle-aged Hispanic woman stands be the outer screen door.
(Spanish accent) Yes?
(friendly) Hi, Mrs. Sanchez.  I'm Chris. We've come to pick up Vera.
(bruskly) She's not going.
She shuts the door in Chris' face.  The group stands ther not knowing what to do next.  V.O.'s from inside the hous they can hear Vera and her mother arguing in Spanish.
What are they saying?
I don't know.  I flunked Spanish.

They all turn to leave when suddenly the front door swing open.  This time Vera, knapsack over her shoulder, ready go, comes out onto the porch.  She's a knockout...20, exo raven-haired beauty...in tight jeans.  They turn and star her.
(forcing a smile) Hi everybody, what're you looking at.  Let's go.
Shelly, intimidated by Vera's sexy good looks, steps behi Andy and slips the mask back over his face.
(to Vera) Is everything okay?
You know, just your basic old fashioned mother problems. (changing the subject) So, where's my date?
Shelly comes out from behind Andy.
(sheepishly) Hi.
(letting her disappointment show) You're Shelly?
I'm sorry.
Andy angrily rips the mask off Shelly's face.
(looking across the street) Hey!  The van's on fire!
White smoke billows out of the van windows, engulfing the vehicle and the luggage tied to the top.
The whole group rushes off the porch and races to the van The first one there, Andy, opens the passenger side door jumps in.  Chris runs around to the driver's side and doe the same.

Through thick, acrid smoke, Chili and her boyfriend, Chuc Cheech and Chong lookalies...can be seen sitting in the b on the floor, each puffing away like crazy on a bong fill with Marijuana.  Each wears a stereo headset that is plug into their own Sony Walkman portable cassette players.
Andy and Chris looks at each other as if to say "I should have known."
Chris' red van speeds along the empty rural highway throu the lush New England countryside.
Through the driver's side window, the wind blows in on Ch and tosses her flaxen hair as she drives.  Debbie sits on Andy's lap in the passenger seat - the only other seat in van.
How much farther to the cottage?
We could've been there already... (looking at Debbie) ...if some people didn't have to go to the bathroom every five minutes.
(defensive) Oh yeah...well just hope that you never get pregnant, 'cause all you do all the time is piss!
Chili and Chuck are sprawled out on the floor, taking inventory of their numerous joints and bags of Marijuana.
Shelly sits cross-legged near the very back of the van, opposite Vera, who sits with her legs open.  Daydreaming, gazes upward at the sky and treetops through the back win

Shelly can't stop staring at Vera, admiring her sexy body Vera senses that Shelly is undressing her with his eyes a quickly turns her head around and catches him looking at breasts.  Shelly averts his eyes in embarrassment and loo over at Chuck who lights up a joint, inhales and hands it Chili.
Is that all you two are gonna do this weekend...smoke dope?
Why not, man?  Is there a law against it?
(persisting) There's better things to do with your life.
(confused) Like what?
(inhaling) I can't think of anything.
She offers the joint to Shelly.  He declines.  Chili offe it to Vera.
Sure, why not.

Vera comes forward on her hands and knees, reaching out f the joint.  As she does, she inadvertently thrusts her shapely rear end almost into Shelly's face.  Shelly makes attempt to retreat from it.  Actually he rather enjoys it
(as she draws on the joint) Is this stuff any good?
Home grown, man!  Of course it's good!
And it's good for you, too. Strictly organic.  No preservatives, man.
Andy sniffs at the air around him filled with the aroma o good grass.
Hey, let's share the wealth with those less fortunate up front here.
Vera passes the joint to him and sits back down across fr Shelly.
Shelly is rummaging through a small black suitcase. It's contents are concealed from Vera's view.
(curious) What d'ya got in there?
(very secretive) My whole world.
In that little thing?
Stick around and you'll see.
Vera turns away and looks out the back window.
We can hear the faint sounds of sirens.
In the distance, two police cruisers, with lights flashin in hot pursuit.
(to the others) Better hide that grass.  It's the cops.
(looking out her sideview mirror) Oh, no.
(looking out the back window) What are we gonna do?
Destroy the evidence, Pronto!
Destroy the evidence?  No, man!
(looking right at Chuck) Yes, man!
They all look at one another, perplexed.  Vera is amused. Without a word and simultaneously, Chili and Chuck begin stuff loose grass and joints into their mouths.
(mouth full) Come on, dig in!
(grabbing a bag) Aw shit!
He starts to eat.  Vera joins in, too.  The police sirens grow louder.
The cruisers advance.
Andy grabs another bag and hands it to Chris.
Here...eat.
Try me some other time.  I'm driving.
Andy turns to Debbie and offers up the cellophane bag.
Breakfast?
No way.  We're pregnant.  Remember?
The sirens seem to be getting closer.  Chili leans in beh Chris.
You better step on it!
The van speeds up, but so do the police cruisers, even narrowing the gap.

Chili, Chuck, Andy and Vera's cheeks are filled to capaci with dope.  Their faces are turning green.  Still they continue to stuff in more at a frantic pace. Shelly holds his black suitcase tightly to his chest as h watches out the back window with concern.
Faster!  Eat faster!
(handing Shelly a fistful of grass) Why don't you help us?
(reluctant) Uh... I guess I'm just not hungry.
(mouth full) You're always hungry!
To appease everybody, Shelly begins to nibble ever so slightly on the marijuana out of Vera's hand.
They're too close.  I gotta pull the van over.  Hurry up and swallow!  Everybody just be cool.
Chris pulls the van to the side of the road.  She sticks head out to watch for the approaching cruisers.  Much to surprise and everyone else's, both police cars zoom by th van without stopping.
A collective sigh of relief, followed by groans of regret what they've just done.
(belching) I think I'm gonna be sick.
(holding her stomach) The line forms at the rear.
I'm gonna be sicker than all of you, man.  Now I gotta spend the whole weekend totally straight... (buries his head in his hands) I don't think I can make it, man!
Chuck... look.
She slowly unbuttons her blouse.  Everyone looks at her, puzzled.  Chuck raises his head.
(mistaking Chili's intentions) Not now, man!
Her fingers reach inside her bra -- but instead of freein her breasts, she pulls out a good size plastic bag of marijuana.  Chuck's mouth drops open.
I'm a slow eater.
(throwing his arms around Chili) I love you, man!
He attacks her with kisses.  The others laugh.
The two police cruisers make a sharp right into the small 'n Pop store parking lot and SCREECH to a halt.
A small group of curious onlookers congregate at the fron entrance of the store.
The cruiser lights continue to flash red and blue as the Police Officers step out of their vehicles.
The Officers order the onlookers to "go home" then enter store.
Chris' red van approaches down the highway.
Chris slows down the vehicle as she sees the flashing pol lights and ambulances.  She rubber-necks to see what's happening.
A team of Medics carry out two heavy body bags from the s
Chris watches with morbid fascination, fueling her anxiet
Debbie is also looking out the window at this unpleasant scene.  She turns to see Chris and reads the concern on h face.
Hey, kiddo... don't let your imagination run away with you.
Chris turns her attention back to the highway and drives

CLOSE SHOT on a PAIR of Scraggly Men's boots as they walk along the edge of the highway.  CAMERA TILTS UP to reveal ABEL... 72, long stringy white hair and whiskered, skinny baggy clothes, weathered stern face.  Like a lone star, h ambles down the lonely highway, dragging a duffle bag.
The SOUND of a vehicle approaching in the distance...
Abel sticks out his right thumb in a hitchhiking stance. affects a smile and looks toward the vehicle down the roa
The sun pours in through the windshield.  Debbie shades h eyes to get a better look at the figure up ahead.
Would you look at that!  I've never seen a senior citizen hitchhiker before.
The others in the back come forward to look.
Let's give the poor old guy a break.  Pick 'im up.
Shelly reacts very emotionally to the suggestion.
That scarecrow?  Can't you tell how weird his is just by looking at him.
Come on, Shelly.  Who else is gonna give him a lift?
Not us!  He's really creepy.
The van is now upon the aged hitchhiker.  He flashes a sm at them:  plaintive, shy, and yet somehow ominous.
(reassuring) He looks just like my grandfather, man.  Let's give him a ride.
The van screeches to a halt and backs up to Abel.  The si door slides open and Abel is lifted into the back.
The van pulls away.
Abel settles into the back next to Shelly who studies the traveller with both curiosity and trepidation.
Chris adjusts her rearview mirror to include Abel.
Abel nods "hello" to one and all.  They nod back.
(in an eloquent soothing voice) You are, all of you, very kind and generous young people to lend a helping hand to a tired, old man. Thank you very much.  Perhaps I can repay the kindness.
The civilized speaking-manner of the shabby-looking stran calms the layer of fear that any might have had.
(continuing) My name is Abel.  And I am my brother's keeper.
Where are you going?
Going?  How do you mean?
I mean, is there any place in particular where we can drop you off?
Drop me off?  How do you mean?
Shelly's suspicions return and he glances from Vera to De and Andy.  Andy shrugs his shoulders.
Abel reaches into his dusty dufflebag and pulls out a ver small bundle wrapped in a scrap of cloth.
Chris watches via the rearview mirror.  Her expression is wary.
Abel unwraps the object and places it in front of Shelly' face.
(continuing) Look what His Grace has brought me.
Shelly looks down at a the small, slimy, white oblong thi
(wincing) What is that?
I found this today.  There were other pieces of the body lying there, but I believe "he" wanted me to have this...
(gasping) That's an eyeball!  Oh, God!
"He" wanted me to warn you. (evangelical) Look at this, all of you!
He holds the eyeball out for each to view.  They shrink b away from him, cringing at the sight.
The eyeball is reflected in the rearview mirror.  Chris i becoming quite upset.
(continuing) See with your own eyes what I have seen.  Runaway!  Go back to where you came from... Now!!!
The van comes to an abrupt stop.  The side door opens and old man is practically tossed out.
On the ground, Abel yells after the van as it speeds away
I warned you!
The van is parked on the shoulder of the highway.
